results.title: Bananas in pyjamas: monster bananas
results.creator_credit: Tony Tilse, Helena Harris and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: B1 and B2, the Teddies and the Rat-in-the-hat are up to their old tricks in ten different stories: “Goldilocks Bananas”, “Magic Carpet”, “Wibbly Wobbly”, “Monster Bananas”, “Morgan’s Cubby”, “Ratmobile”, “Strictly Bananas”, “Shadow Painting”, “Banana Shop” and “Mirror Mirror.” Some of the escapades include B1 and B2 disguising themselves as sea-monsters when they find some seaweed on the beach and their crazy attempts at carpentry where they try to mend furniture but end up redesigning it instead!

results.title: Bananas in pyjamas: it's music time!
results.creator_credit: Tony Tilse, Sophia Turkiewicz, Helena Harris and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: B1 and B2 and their friends the Teddies embark on eight terrific adventures. Includes two fun filled songs as well as the famous “Bananas in pyjamas” signature song. All the episodes have a musical theme.

results.title: Bananas in pyjamas birthday special
results.brief_description: The bananas, B1 and B2 and the teddies Amy, Lulu and Morgan have lots of fun together and they get up to lots of mischief as well. “Cuddles Avenue” - the naughty bananas decide to play a trick on the teddies. “Birthday Week” - it’s the bananas’ birthday on Friday and the excitement builds as the teddies prepare a surprise party. “Wet Paint” - Amy and Morgan can’t resist touching the brand new paint of the park bench, just to see if it is really wet. “Fancy Dress” - the bananas and teddies have been invited to a fancy dress party.

results.title: Ballads of Bullant Ridge. No. 1
results.creator_credit: Chris Gallagher, Alan Marshall, Ronald Mason and Academy Film Productions
results.brief_description: A series of bush ballad songs based on the “Speewa Jack” characters from the Alan Marshall stories illustrated by cartoonist Douglas Trainsh. The songs are ‘The Strongest man in town’; ‘The Boxing kangaroo’; and ‘Goanna oil’.

results.title: Bamboozled [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Spike Lee, Jon Kilik and 40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks
results.brief_description: Shot on digital video (by cinematographer Ellen Kuras) and taking it’s title from a Malcolm X speech (“You’ve been led astray, led amok, you’ve been bamboozled”), Spike Lee’s “Bamboozled” is an ambitious and contentious satire, a dazzling balancing act that at times strains under it’s own ingenuity but never fails to provoke and challenge. Damon Wayans stars as a successful and affected television executive, Pierre Delacroix, who is pressured by his wannabe home-boy boss (Michael Rapaport) to create a hit series tailored for African Americans. Frustrated by the implicit racism that dominates the entertainment industry, Delacroix comes up with a show that he feels white America really wants to see, a minstrel show called ‘Mantan - The New Millennium Minstrel Show’. His offensive joke backfires however when ‘Mantan’ becomes a runaway success. Lee takes firm pot shots at various institutions, interspersing the film with racially coded advertising and racist images from America’s shameful filmic past (including much loved American classics, “Birth of a nation” and “Gone with the wind”). Not surprising then that Lee dedicates the film to Budd Schulberg, the writer of Eliza Kazan’s 1957 media satire, “A face in the crowd”. Cast includes Jada Pinkett-Smith, Savion Glover and Tommy Davidson.

results.title: Ballade Pour Un Chien = Ballad for a Dog
results.brief_description:
Remy Viachet is a lonely old man with money worries. During one of his solitary walks, he finds a stray dog and decides to adopt him. Remy manages to sneak the dog in his appartment unbeknown to the concierge. One day the old man is found dead in his flat, the floor littered with dog food tins intended for an animal that does not seem to exist.

Credits: Director, Gerard Vergez ; writers, Maurice Curry, Gerard Vergez ; photography, Patrice Pouget ; music, Francois Rabbath.
Cast: Charles Vanel, Julien Guiomar, Claude Genia, Colette Regis, Alfred Lenglet.

results.title: Bamboo: plant of a thousand uses
results.creator_credit: Robert Lang, Sterling S Beath and Bailey Film Productions
results.brief_description: Although this is a film about the traditional and everyday uses of bamboo, it also portrays many aspects of contemporary living in Japan; life in urban centres and rural areas and aspects of agriculture, handicrafts, art and types of shelter are explored. This giant grass is noted for its beauty and commercial value and it provides a livelihood for many Japanese families.

results.title: Ballad of a young man = Wadjah seorang laki-laki
results.creator_credit: Teguh Karya, Turino Djunaidy and Sarinande Films
results.brief_description: Nineteenth century Dutch Batavia serves as a backdrop to influential Indonesian director Teguh Karya’s first feature. ‘Ballad of a Young Man’ is about Amallo, a local of Portuguese descent, and his troubled relationship with his womanising father. His father is an important man in the village who works for the Dutch, keeping watch over their horses. Amallo, on the other hand, is a rebel who steals ammunition and horses from the Dutch soldiers. When Amallo returns to his village after spending some time in the city, he is betrayed by his best friend who is consumed with jealousy. Meanwhile, Amallo’s father has been promoted by the Dutch for recovering stolen horses. The film is told in flashback, a favourite storytelling technique of the director (see also ‘Bitter Coffee’). Slamet Rahardjo - protege of Teguh Karya - now Head of the Film Council and a prominent figure in Indonesia, makes his acting debut as Amallo. Cast also includes W.D. Mochtar and Rima Melati. In Indonesian with English subtitles.

results.title: Bambi
results.creator_credit: David D. Hand, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.credit_line:
Disney Studio Artist

Story sketch

Coloured pencil and graphite on paper
results.material_description: Coloured pencil and graphite on paper
results.brief_description: Acknowledged by generations of moviegoers as one of the greatest Disney animated classics ever produced, this extraordinary movie miracle is most fondly remembered as Walt Disney’s favourite picture. The simple, heartwarming story of the newborn ‘prince of the forest’ reflects the universal joy in us all as we discover the wonders of life and the beauty of nature. Each new revelation, along with bashful Flower and fun-loving Thumper, elevate this beloved classic to the status of timeless masterpiece. Nominated for five Academy Awards.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David D. Hand, Walt Disney and Walt Disney Productions
results.description:
Walt Disney Animation Studio’s Bambi (1943) is one of the most visually striking and emotionally resonant and endearing animated features that the studio has ever produced. From the realistic animal animation and vivid, impressionistic backgrounds to the coming-of-age story at its centre, Bambi changed the way the studio approached animation and established one of its signature looks.

Walt Disney famously brought two fawns (baby deer) into the studio to help his animators create realistic illustrations. To get the attitudes and movements of animals in the wild right, he filmed hours of footage for the animators, and even had them study animal anatomy. But the cheerful faces of Bambi, Thumper and Flower were designed by an animator studying the expressions of human babies. When he translated those looks onto the drawings of animals, the adorable and expressive animal faces that have been the hallmark of the Studio’s subsequent films was born. The early concept sketch featured above is one of the earliest examples of this type of animation, and shows Bambi meeting his future friend Flower.

Friendship and love are at the heart of Bambi, which follows the princely deer from birth to adolescence and adulthood, with the trials and hardships of life also never overlooked. Instead, the film teaches audiences how to overcome life’s bitter winters, knowing that spring is always on its way. Apart from containing an ageless wisdom, Bambi is also one of the world’s first environmental films, which considers the destructive intrusion of man on nature, but its overarching message of peace, acceptance and harmony shows audiences there’s nothing love can’t conquer.
